name: Frankincense
shortDescription: Sacred aromatic resin used in Temple incense, representing purity and divine presence
fullDescription: Frankincense (Hebrew: ◊ú÷∞◊ë◊ï÷π◊†÷∏◊î levonah, meaning 'white') is a precious aromatic resin obtained from Boswellia trees native to Arabia and East Africa. In Jewish tradition, frankincense was a key ingredient in the sacred Temple incense (Ketoret) and was burned on the golden altar twice daily. Its pure white appearance and sweet fragrance made it the perfect symbol of purity and divine worship. Frankincense was also placed on the showbread in the Temple and offered with certain grain offerings. The substance was so valuable it was considered a fitting gift for kings and deities, as seen when the Magi brought it to the infant Jesus.

properties.name: Source
properties.value: Resin from Boswellia sacra and related trees

properties.name: Appearance
properties.value: White or pale yellow crystalline resin

properties.name: Fragrance
properties.value: Sweet, woody, slightly citrus when burned

properties.name: Temple Use
properties.value: Component of Ketoret (sacred incense), burned twice daily

properties.name: Showbread
properties.value: Placed on the Table of Showbread in the Temple

properties.name: Symbolism
properties.value: Purity, prayer ascending to heaven, divine presence

properties.name: Value
properties.value: Precious commodity, equal to gold in ancient trade

mythologyContexts.usage: Frankincense was essential in Temple worship as part of the Ketoret (sacred incense blend) burned twice daily on the golden altar. It was also placed on the showbread and added to certain grain offerings. Its pure white color and ascending fragrance symbolized prayers rising to heaven and the purity required in divine service.

rituals.name: Daily Incense Offering
rituals.description: Frankincense was burned twice daily as part of the Ketoret on the golden altar

rituals.name: Showbread Ritual
rituals.description: Pure frankincense was placed alongside the twelve loaves of showbread

rituals.name: Grain Offerings
rituals.description: Frankincense accompanied certain meal offerings (mincha) in the Temple

rituals.name: Yom Kippur Service
rituals.description: Special incense offering including frankincense on the Day of Atonement

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Frankincense's white color represents purity and holiness. When burned, its fragrant smoke ascends upward, symbolizing prayers and worship rising to heaven. In Kabbalistic thought, frankincense corresponds to the highest Sefirot (Keter and Chokmah), representing the purest forms of divine emanation. The expensive and rare nature of frankincense teaches that we should offer our finest to God. Its inclusion in the Ketoret alongside less pleasant ingredients (like galbanum) teaches the importance of communal worship including all types of people.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Frankincense trade routes shaped ancient economies, connecting Arabia to the Mediterranean world. The Queen of Sheba likely brought frankincense among her gifts to Solomon. In mystical Judaism, reciting the Ketoret formula (including frankincense's preparation) is considered spiritually protective and elevating. Modern synagogues often use frankincense in havdalah spice boxes. The gift of frankincense to Jesus by the Magi connects Jewish Temple practice to Christian tradition.

mythologyContexts.usage: Frankincense was among the most sacred substances in ancient Egypt, burned daily in temples to honor the gods, especially Ra. The rising smoke was believed to carry prayers to the heavens and please the divine nostrils. Egyptians burned frankincense during the morning temple rituals when Ra's statue was awakened, washed, dressed, and fed. The resin was also used in mummification, fumigation rituals, and as a component in kyphi (sacred perfume). Like myrrh, frankincense was imported from the Land of Punt, making it extremely valuable and associated with divine presence.

rituals.name: Daily Temple Ritual
rituals.description: Frankincense burned three times daily - dawn, noon, and dusk - to honor Ra

rituals.name: Kyphi Preparation
rituals.description: Frankincense as key ingredient in sacred kyphi perfume used in evening temple rites

rituals.name: Fumigation Rites
rituals.description: Frankincense used to purify temples, homes, and sacred spaces

rituals.name: Royal Ceremonies
rituals.description: Frankincense burned during coronations and royal festivals

textReferences.context: Incense purifies and makes the king divine
Frankincense trees brought from Punt as divine tribute
Ramesses III's gifts of frankincense to temples
Burning incense to illuminate the path for the deceased

mythologyContexts.symbolism: Frankincense embodied solar divinity and the presence of the gods. Its white color represented purity and the clean desert from which it came. When burned, the ascending smoke symbolized the soul's journey to heaven and prayers rising to the gods. The fragrance itself was considered the 'sweat of the gods' or divine perfume, making sacred spaces truly holy. In solar theology, frankincense represented Ra's divine essence made manifest - light, purity, and life-giving power.
mythologyContexts.culturalSignificance: Frankincense was so valuable in ancient Egypt that pharaohs organized expensive expeditions to Punt to secure steady supplies. Hatshepsut's Punt expedition (c. 1470 BCE) specifically sought frankincense trees to plant in her temple at Deir el-Bahari. Temple inventories list frankincense among the most precious offerings. The substance was central to Egyptian concepts of purity, divine presence, and proper worship. Egyptian use of frankincense influenced Greek, Roman, and later Christian incense traditions throughout the Mediterranean world.

linguistic.etymology: From Hebrew root ◊ú◊ë◊ü (l-b-n) meaning 'white', referring to the white/pale color of frankincense resin. Related to ◊ú÷∏◊ë÷∏◊ü (lavan, 'white') and ◊ú÷∞◊ë÷∏◊†÷∏◊î (levanah, 'moon').

originPoint.name: Jerusalem (Temple Mount)
originPoint.description: Used in Temple rituals in Jerusalem, though the frankincense itself was imported from Arabia (Yemen/Oman) and East Africa (Somalia)

temporal.timelinePosition: First Temple (1000-586 BCE) and Second Temple (516 BCE-70 CE)

firstAttestation.description: Torah (Exodus, Leviticus) prescribing frankincense for Temple incense and offerings

historicalDate.display: 1000 BCE - 70 CE (First and Second Temple periods)
